FX

COMMODITIES

OPEC monthly report stated that OPEC crude production fell 41k bpd in June to average 32.32mln bpd, according to secondary sources. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

A twitter source initially reported US Pastor Brunson is to be released from house arrest in Turkey on August 15th citing the US embassy in Ankara, however an official for the embassy stated shortly after that they have not issued a statement regarding US Pastor Brunson. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan stated that attacks on the economy will continue for a while and there is no economic basis for FX developments, while he added they will continue to take the necessary steps in the face of these attacks and that the exchange rate will go back to rational levels. (Newswires)

White House stated that National Security Adviser Bolton met with Turkish Ambassador Kilic at the White House in which they discussed pastor Brunson and US-Turkey relations, while the meeting was said to be at the Turkish ambassador's request. (Newswires)
 

US

US White House Economic Adviser Hassett said a trade deal with Mexico is very close. Elsewhere, Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau stated the NAFTA framework can be improved to benefit all three parties and added they will have more to say about steel trade soon. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US stocks finished negative with sentiment dampened amid an EM currency sell-off on Turkey contagion fears. This saw all majors finish in the red in which the S&P 500 and DJIA notched a 4th consecutive loss, while losses were led by financials, materials and energy with the latter the worst hit following a slide in crude in which WTI briefly fell below USD 66.00/bbl before rebounding heading into the settlement. In stock specifics, Nielsen Holdings PLC (NLSN) surged more than 11% after it had been confronted by activist investor Elliot Management, who has taken an 8% stake in an effort to get the company to sell itself. Sysco (SYY) were also higher on Monday following its earnings beating on EPS, but revenues were in line. Harley Davidson (HOG) were hit as Trump continues with his witchhunt of the co, after he tweeted ‘Many @harleydavidson owners plan to boycott the company if manufacturing moves overseas. Great!’. VF Corp (VFC) also suffered losses after sources confirmed reports from last week that it is to spin off its Lee & Wrangler jeans into a public company; it is estimating a onetime expense of 5c this quarter as well as USD 1bln of debt to be added to the balance sheet noting it will have no effect on the FY19 financial outlook. Tesla (TSLA) announced an update today where it stated the board was notified of the consideration to go private on August 2nd and said the Saudi’s have reached out for another meeting where the MD of the fund showed support for funding the privatisation, at this time. The report also stated most of the capital required will be through equity and not debt, and it replied to the required debt rumour of USD 70bln as a dramatic overstatement. Later, WSJ reported The Saudi fund is said to consider increasing its 5% stake in Tesla (TSLA). Elsewhere, Citron research were positive on Twitter (TWTR) giving them a yearly target of USD 52, and Diebold Nixdorf (DBD) is said to have hired advisors to look at a sale. SPX -0.4% at 2821, NDX -0.1% at 7401, DJI -0.5% at 25187.

Treasury yields rebounded from the 4-week lows seen in recent. The complex edged lower after the Turkish Central Bank announced liquidity release on Monday contributing to easing some global tensions. The yield curve saw some modest bear-steepening as most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve where 30yr yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. 5s30s and 10s30s widened by c.1.5bps, 2s5s narrowed by c.1bps. US 10YR T-notes settled 4 ticks lower at 120-08.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th August 2018 - USDTRY hits 7.200+; OPEC forecasts 2019 oil surplus
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Lira continues its descent, Equities down, Treasuries down, crude down, dollar flat.
  • REAR-VIEW: USDTRY hit highs at 7.200+ and spreads to EM, OPEC June report crude production down 41k & forecasts lower demand, Russian retaliation on hold as US unclear.
  • AHEAD: Chinese Retail Sales & Industrial Output; German GDP and ZEW Survey; UK Employment Data; weekly APIs; Earnings from HD.

* TURKEY: Developments over in Turkey continued to worry global markets on Monday, as the TRY continued to slide, hitting lows at 7.200+ before paring back some of the losses as the central bank vowed to release liquidity and reduced the Reserve Requirement Ratios for non-core FX liabilities by 400BPS alongside the Lira Required Reserve reduced by 250BPS for all maturities. The Central Bank was also said to meet banks' TRY liquidity needs at an overnight rate of 19.25% after not opening the regular daily repo auction at 17.75% today due to unhealthy price formations.

Turkish President Erdogan noted the attacks on the economy will continue for a while and added there is no economic basis for FX developments. He announced he will continue to take the necessary steps in the face of these attacks and he expects the exchange rate to go back to rational levels. Elsewhere, an US embassy official in Ankara dismissed unconfirmed reports on social media that Pastor Brunson, a detainee in Turkey which spurred the initial sanctions, would be released on August 15th noting a statement has not been issued.

* NAFTA: Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau said the NAFTA framework can be improved to benefit all three parties stating ‘we will have more to say about steel trade soon’.

* GEOPOLITICS: Russia's Kremlin said Putin has not yet given any orders on drawing up retaliatory sanctions against the US because the scope of planned US measures is unclear. Kremlin added that they have been pushing for an agreement with all countries to conduct trade through national currencies, echoing calls made by Turkey's Erdogan. Over in Iran, the Iranian Foreign Minister reported Iran will not change its policies in the Middle East due to US sanctions and threats whilst Khamenei has refused Trump's talks, stating there is nothing new.

* SPX -0.4% at 2821, NDX -0.1% at 7401, DJI -0.5% at 25187. SECTORS: Energy -0.94%, Materials -0.9%, Industrials -0.37% Cons Discretionary +0.1%, Cons Staples -0.29%, Healthcare +0.11%, Financials -0.7%, Tech +0.02%, Telecoms -0.1%, Utilities +0.22%.

Nielsen Holdings PLC (NLSN) surged more than 11% after it had been confronted by activist investor Elliot Management, who has taken an 8% stake in an effort to get the company to sell itself. Sysco (SYY) were also higher on Monday following its earnings beating on EPS, but revenues were in line.

Harley Davidson (HOG) were hit as Trump continues with his witchhunt of the co, after he tweeted ‘Many @harleydavidson owners plan to boycott the company if manufacturing moves overseas. Great!’. VF Corp (VFC) also suffered losses after sources confirmed reports from last week that it is to spin off its Lee & Wrangler jeans into a public company; it is estimating a onetime expense of 5c this quarter as well as USD 1bln of debt to be added to the balance sheet noting it will have no effect on the FY19 financial outlook.

Tesla (TSLA) announced an update today where it stated the board was notified of the consideration to go private on August 2nd and said the Saudi’s have reached out for another meeting where the MD of the fund showed support for funding the privatisation, at this time. The report also stated most of the capital required will be through equity and not debt, and it replied to the required debt rumour of USD 70bln as a dramatic overstatement. Later, WSJ reported The Saudi fund is said to consider increasing its 5% stake in Tesla (TSLA).

Elsewhere, Citron research were positive on Twitter (TWTR) giving them a yearly target of USD 52, and Diebold Nixdorf (DBD) is said to have hired advisors to look at a sale.

* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (U8) SETTLE  43C LOWER AT USD 67.20/BBL; BRENT CRUDE FUTURES (V8) SETTLE 20C LOWER AT USD 72.61/BBL. WTI & Brent crude futures were relatively unreactive this morning with the OPEC Monthly report resulting in little to no reaction, however prices then took a hit in late morning trade which coincided with the weekly Genscape release, with newswires suggesting the inventory data showed a build from the previous week. Nonetheless oil pared back most of those losses heading into settlements, but still ended the session in negative territory.  Tomorrow’s API is expected to show a draw in Crude by 3.27mln, Distillates to build by 0.9mln and Gasoline to draw by 0.8mln.

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT. Monday saw the release of the monthly OPEC report where secondary sources stated OPEC crude production fell 41k BPD in June to an average of 32.32.mln BPD. The report showed that output increased mostly in Kuwait, Nigeria, UAE and Iraq, whilst production showed declines in Libya, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. Oil demand growth for 2018 is anticipated to increase by 1.64mln BPD, 20k BPD lower than last month’s projections, mainly due to weaker-than-expected oil demand data from Latin America and the Middle East in Q218. 2019 world oil demand is expected to grow 1.43mln BPD, also 20k BPD lower than the previous report. Non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 was revised higher by 73k BPD from the previous report to an average of 59.62mln BPD, a 2.08mln BPD increase y/y. Non-OPEC oil supply in 2019 is expected to average 61.75mln BPD, showing an upward revision of 106k BPD.

* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE 4 TICKS LOWER AT  120-08.

Treasury yields rebounded from the 4-week lows seen in recent. The complex edged lower after the Turkish Central Bank announced liquidity release on Monday contributing to easing some global tensions. The yield curve saw some modest bear-steepening as most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve where 30yr yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. 5s30s and 10s30s widened by c.1.5bps, 2s5s narrowed by c.1bps.

* TRY: The Lira’s fortunes continue to dominate, and a recurring theme appears to be panning out as verbal intervention, especially from President Erdogan largely ineffectual or even compounding Try weakness vs physical measures to turn try and the tide. Indeed, if there was any doubt about some of the sources of investor angst, the fact that various moves implemented by the CBRT to stem the tide actually seem to have helped (via deep RRR cuts and FX swap limits) highlights the importance of its independence, while reports that US Pastor Brunson may be released also underpinned the Lira even though rejected by the US Embassy in Ankara. USDTRY has settled back under 7.0000 vs 7.2000+ at one stage, albeit still well off sub-6.5000 lows before the Executive President’s latest battle cries.

* ZAR, MXN, RUB and CNH also weakened further, but recovered some losses alongside the TRY, along with the BRL after Brazil’s Government stated it is prepared to intervene in FX and bond markets vs the SARB that is not yet ready to act.

* USD: In contrast, the Dollar and index retreated from best levels with the DXY down below 96.200 at one stage vs 96.530 at the new YTD peak, but still bid by virtue of net gains vs some G10 counterparts.

* NZD, GBP, EUR, CAD: All ending Monday’s EU session firmer vs the Greenback, following whippy moves earlier, with the Kiwi back towards the top of a 0.6595-50 range and AUDNZD testing bids around 1.1050, while Cable is inching closer to 1.2800 vs 1.2730 lows and the single currency is trading on either sides of 1.1400, but not troubling offers said to be waiting at 1.1440-50, yet. The Loonie has rebounded from 1.3175 lows to test near term chart support reported in the 1.3150-20 area.

* AUD, JPY, CHF: The AUD has been lagging throughout with most to lose from an all-out US-China trade fall out and still tracking YUAN moves more closely than other G10s as a result. AUDUSD has bounced off worst levels, but remains capped ahead of 0.7300, while USDJPY has extended the upside of its range to 110.90+ and the Franc held within relatively tight 0.9920-55 trading parameters.

* COMING-UP: UK Labour Market Report. On Tuesday the UK will release its most recent labour market data, with market participants looking for justification of the BoE’s hike on August 8th. Wage growth remains the focus, with Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) expected at 2.7%. This would mean that wages marginally exceeded headline CPI and developed real income growth for the 5th consecutive month. Coupling this with an unemployment rate forecast to stay at 4.2% in spite of fewer jobs added to the economy than previously (98k vs. 137k Prev.) would support the BoE’s rhetoric of a tightening labour market and may offer a floor to a GBP that has been sliding ever since the BoE’s meeting on August 8th, Brussels permitting, of course.

13th August 2018

Earnings

Sysco Corp (SYY) Q2 EPS USD 0.94 vs. Exp. USD 0.93, revenue USD 15.3bln vs. Exp. USD 15.3bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • 3M (MMM) - Dr. Dambisa F. Moyo has been elected to the board of directors; effective August 12th. (Newswires)
  • Apple (AAPL) – Ralph Nader, AN American political activist, has expressed concerns on how the tech giant is spending its excess money stating it could have hired more employees and strengthened pensions with the USD 100bln spent in buybacks. (NPR)
  • International Business Machine (IBM) – The co.’s Watson AI product, which focuses on cancer care, is not providing much support to doctors and patients. The co. invested billions in the product but the ‘diagnosis is gloomy’. (WSJ)
  • JPMorgan Chase (JPM) - The bank’s credit card users can soon benefit from more flight and hotel options after it partnered up with Expedia (EXPE) over the weekend. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – CEO Nadella discloses the sale of 328,000 common shares in the co. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) - Discount retailer Don Quijote Holdings (TYO 7532) has said they are interested in acquiring Walmart's Japanese Supermarket chain, Seiyu. There has been no indication from Walmart that they are willing to sell Seiyu at this particular time. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Accenture (ACN) – The co. enters a strategic agreement with China-based Along Technologies, an AI start-up. (Newswires)  
  • Alaska Air (ALK) – A co. employee stole and crashed a plane with no passengers on board over the weekend. (Newswires)
  • AMD (AMD) – The co. launched Radeon Pro WX 8200 which delivers ‘the world's best workstation graphics performance for under USD 1,000’ the co. says. (Newswires)
  • Harley Davidson (HOG) – US President Trump backs the boycott of the co. in a tweet ‘Many @harleydavidson owners plan to boycott the company if manufacturing moves overseas. Great! Most other companies are coming in our direction, including Harley competitors. A really bad move! U.S. will soon have a level playing field, or better.’ (Twitter)
  • Air Products (APD) – The co. is to form a JV with Saudi Aramco under which Air Products will purchase assets from Saudi Aramco for more than USD 8bln and will hold 55% of the JV. (Newswires)
  • Nielsen Holdings PLC (NLSN) - The TV-ratings co. has been confronted by activist investor Elliot Management, who has taken an 8% stake in an effort to get Nielsen to sell itself. Elliot will encourage Nielsen to 'undertake a full strategic review'. (Newswires)
  • US-listed Chinese education providers (TAL, EDU) – A new Chinese legislation may pose a limit to growth through M&As. (Newswires)
  • VF Corp (VFC) - The co. will de-merge its denim business, Lee & Wrangler, into its own public company. This will allow VF Corp to focus more on its successful brands: Vans Shoes and The North Face. The co. elects Scott Baxter as CEO, Rustin Welton as CFO of New Co. (Newswires)
  • Newell Brands (NWL) – ACON Investments acquires the co.’s unit Goody Products; terms not disclosed. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) –The bank wants part of the government-held student debt and is looking to refinance the government through private loans. (Newswires)
  • Express Scripts (ESRX) / Cigna (CI) – Glass Lewis recommends Express Scripts’ stockholders to vote in favour of the merger deal with Cigna. (Newswires)
  • Tractor Supply (TSCO) – The co. promotes Steve Barbarick to President and COO. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s positive on Twitter (TWTR), Square (SQ), Equinix (EQIX).
  • Barron’s negative on Kraft Heinz (KHC).
  • Barron’s says LyondellBasell (LYB) cheap. Also says retail stocks including Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF), Urban Outfitters (URBN), American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) are cheap after getting hit hard by Amazon (AMZN).

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) - Privacy issues remain a concern after an Associated Press investigation revealed that even when location history is turned off many apps still record your location in their databases. Separately, as the Google search engine remains blocked in China, the co. is working with allies in the country providing support to app developers and it is testing an app version of its search engine that would adhere to Chinese rules. Lokman Tsui, a Google's ex former head of free expression for Asia and the Pacific, noted a censored search engine in China is ‘not right’ as it is a violation of human rights. (Newswires/WSJ/The Intercept)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL)/Facebook (FB) – The two tech giants have reportedly hurt online advertising firms for several years and therefore are forcing consolidation among start-ups as they face slower revenues and reduced money flow. (NY Times)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – Subsidiary Twitch, a streaming video platform, removes Communities and replaces them with a tag system to better describe the content of streams. (Newswires)
  • Broadcasting groups (DIS, FOXA, SBGI, GOOGL, AMZN, BX, APO) – Disney is to sell 22 21st Century Fox’s (FOXA) sports networks as part of its USD 71.3bln deal for the co.’s assets. As Fox holds rights to 44 basketball, baseball and hockey teams, an auction valued at USD 20bln is attracting interest from Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI), Google's (GOOGL) YouTube and Amazon (AMZN) as well as Blackstone Group (BX), CVC Capital Partners and Apollo Global Management (APO). (Newswires)
  • Spotify (SPOT) – The music app is reportedly looking to allow free users to skip though ads an unlimited number of times. (AdAge)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund showed no interest in funding the proposed USD 72bln deal to take the automaker private despite building a minority stake in the co. Similarly, Softbank (SFTBF) it is not planning to support the buyout and shifts focus on car makers such as General Motors’s (GM) autonomous vehicles unit. Separately, Keller Lenkner LLC reported a class action suit was commenced against CEO Elon Musk claiming he violated the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by issuing false and misleading statements regarding Musk taking the company private. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Amicus Therapeutics (FOLD) – The FDA has granted accelerated approval for Gelafold for the treatment of Fabry Disease. (Newswires)
  • Cheniere Energy (LNG) - The energy producer has signed a USD 25bln deal with Taiwan's state-owned CPC for a 25-year supply agreement. (Newswires)
  • Ctrip.com (CTRP) - Following the slide in the Lira, the Chinese travel agency has said it is no longer accepting Lira as some customers have been exploiting the fluctuations in the currency. (Newswires)
  • Flex (FLEX) – President Francois Barbier sells 70,278 ordinary shares in the co. (Newswires)
  • Hilton Grand Vacations (HGV) - CFO James Mikolaichik has been terminated from the board following his conduct and behavior which was inconsistent with the company's policies. (Newswires)
  • Janus Henderson Group (JHG) – The co. announced a Q2 dividend of USD 0.36/shr. (Newswires)
  • KKR (KKR) – The co. is to build a 60% stake in Ramky Enviro Engineers for around USD 530mln.Seperately, the global investment firm says that the upcoming IPO of its Indian unit will exclude its Private Equity operations. (Newswires)
  • Papa John’s (PZZA) – The co. launched a new assistance programme for franchises in the US and Canada by lowering fees charges to assist the sales and operating challenges of the co. following the departure of the restaurant chain’s founder. (Newswires)

OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production fell 41k bpd in June to average 32.32mln bpd, according to secondary sources
content:
• Crude oil output increased mostly in Kuwait, Nigeria, UAE and Iraq, while production showed declines in Libya, I.R. Iran, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.
  • In 2018, oil demand growth is anticipated to increase by 1.64mln bpd, 20k bpd lower than last month’s projections, mainly due to weaker-than-expected oil demand data from Latin America and the Middle East in Q218.
  • For 2019, world oil demand is forecast to grow by 1.43mln bpd, also some 20k bpd lower than last month’s assessment.
  • Non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 was revised up by 73k bpd from the previous MOMR to average 59.62 mln bpd, representing an increase of 2.08mln bpd Y/Y.
  • Non-OPEC oil supply in 2019 is projected to reach an average of 61.75mln bpd, indicating an upward revision by 106k bpd

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities kick-start the week lower across the board (Eurostoxx 50 -0.6%) with sentiment in the region soured by contagion concerns
  • USD/TRY soared through 7.0000 to a new record peak around 7.2150, and prompted the CBRT into action
  • Looking ahead, today’s calendar lacks tier 1 data

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower across the board with sentiment in the region spooked on spill-over concerns as the Turkish lira extended on last week’s slump following a defiant tone from Turkish President Erdogan, which triggered capital control concerns and who labelled the weakness in TRY as a ‘currency plot’. This pressured the major indices from the get-go with ASX 200 (-0.4%) dragged by mining names, while Nikkei 225 (-2.0%) underperformed on safe-haven flows into JPY and with Mitsui Mining & Smelting down 15% post-earnings. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) were also heavily weighed alongside the broad EM-triggered mayhem and continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices underpinned by safe-haven demand, although upside was also capped amid a lack of Rinban announcement with the BoJ only in the market for Treasury discount bills.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8629 (Prev. 6.8395)

TURKEY

Turkish President Erdogan stated the economy is not in a crisis and that weakness in TRY is a currency plot, while he added that Turkey will win this economic war and are undergoing preparations to use national currencies for trade with nations such as China and Russia. There were also comments from Turkish Finance Minister Albayrak that the government has an action plan regarding the currency and will take necessary measures on Monday to ease market concerns, while he stated they will not convert nor seize FX deposits and that the currency is being directly targeted by the US President. In related news, Turkish Presidency Communication Chief Altun stated Erdogan’s comments were a warning against FX flight, while the banking regulator also announced to limit swap transactions in which banks’ total swap transactions has been capped at 50% of banks’ equity. (Newswires)

Turkish Central Bank has reduced the Reserve Requirement Ratios for non-core FX liabilities by 400BPS alongside the Lira Required Reserve reduced by 250BPS for all maturities. Turkey’s Central Bank will meet banks' TRY liquidity needs at overnight rate of 19.25% after not opening the regular daily repo auction at 17.75% today due to unhealthy price formations, according to bankers. This could be the first step towards tightening policy through interest rate corridors, adding banks may not use overnight funding today due to low TRY liquidity needs; according to bankers. (Newswires)

Turkish Foreign Ministry stated that Turkey will retaliate as necessary to the latest US tariffs after President Trump tweeted that he authorised a double up on tariffs on steel and aluminium with respect to Turkey. (Newswires)

Turkish market regulator is warning against misleading rumours in the media which could result in fines or even prison time. (Newswires)

Turkish Presidential spokesman said the Treasury, Central Bank and Banking watchdog are taking necessary steps. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Trade experts warn UK PM May the Brexit tariff plan is “fanciful”, while also questioning the reliability to track goods. (Times)

Senior Brussel figure stated the immediate consequence of a no-deal Brexit could be worse for the EU than the UK. This comes ahead of the next round of Brexit talks scheduled for Thursday. (Times)

The UK is working on options to avoid a hard border with Ireland; according to people familiar with the matter. One option would effectively prolong large parts of the transition phase; according to one official. (Newswires)

According to a major new poll, more than 100 parliamentary seats that backed Brexit in 2016 have flipped to support staying in the EU. (Sky News)

US President Trump stated that a deal with Mexico is coming along nicely and that Canada must wait. (Twitter/Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea reportedly rejected several denuclearization proposals made by the US, while South Korea and North Korea are said to hold a summit in September. (CNN/Yonhap)

Officials on Friday stated that Iran conducted a test launch of a ballistic missile which was its first for the year. (Fox)

Russian Finance Minister Siluanov stated that Russia will further reduce holdings of US securities in response to sanctions, but is not planning to shut down US firms. Additionally, Russian Finance Minister said Russia is to halt FX purchases for reserve, as speculated. Meanwhile, Russia's Kremlin said President Putin has not yet given any orders on drawing up retaliatory sanctions against the US as the scope of planned US measures is unclear. (FT/Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities kick-start the week lower across the board  (Eurostoxx 50 -0.6%) with sentiment in the region soured by contagion concerns as the Turkish Lira extends on last week’s slump. As such, Turkey-exposed banks plumb the depths again with BNP Paribas (-1.0%), BBVA (-3.7%) and Unicredit (-3.2%) all near the foot of their respective bourses. Elsewhere, Germany’s DAX 30 is dragged lower by its third largest constituent, Bayer (-11.2%), after recently acquired Monsanto was ordered to pay USD 289mln in fines as a court ruled the company’s weedkiller caused cancer.

FIXED INCOME

The 10 year EU benchmarks probed a bit further either side of parity in recent trade, but have reverted to sit flat or very close to previous settlement levels amidst the ongoing EM malaise and other areas of risk, ie from global trade/tariff rifts, the Brexit stalemate and Italy’s new Government challenging the EU’s fiscal rules. Bunds and Gilts climbed to fresh intraday highs of 163.53 and 123.74 respectively before retreating to revisit or set new session lows on Eurex and Liffe at 163.22 and 123.50, but are now back to within a handful of ticks from unchanged, while US Treasuries are nearer overnight troughs, but rangy and the curve a little steeper against the backdrop of marginally lower Fed hike expectations. 

FX

TRY - The Lira remains front and centre of attention after more rousing attempts by Turkish President Erdogan to shore up the currency and coral support from the international investor community largely fell on deaf ears, with Usd/Try soaring through 7.0000 to a new record peak around 7.2150, and prompting the CBRT into action. However, still unable to intervene via conventional means (ie rate hikes) the Bank resorted to cutting Reserve Requirement Ratios for non-core FX liabilities by 400 bp alongside the Lira Required Reserve by 250 bp for all maturities, and the relief has been relatively limited as a result.

EM - Lira contagion has spread further across the region, with the Rand hit especially hard (Usd/Zar 15.4700+ at one stage , but the Idr, Twn and other Asian units also weakening to intervention tolerance levels, while the Mxn has unwound more NAFTA-related gains to trade back below 19.0000 vs the Usd.

DXY - Riding high amidst all the turmoil in high-beta/risk/yield currency counterparts, with the index just off fresh 2018 highs at 96.530, and now looking at chart targets ahead of 97.000 with fair resistance seen around 96.841.

JPY - Still bucking overall trends and outperforming due to its ultra safe-haven allure, with Usd/Jpy pulling back further from 111.00 and through 110.50 to test the water ahead of 110.00 where decent expiry option interest resides (1.3 bn up to 110.05 to be precise).

AUD/EUR - The biggest G10 losers and most adversely impacted by broad risk aversion again, with Aud/Usd sitting mid-range between 0.7250-0.7300 and the single currency down through 1.1400 to test the 200 WMA at 1.1360 before regaining a degree of composure.

CAD/GBP/CHF/NZD - The Loonie is holding within a 1.3140-75 range vs its US rival and well off recent highs as Canada’s diplomatic row with Saudi Arabia rumbles on, while Cable has pared some losses from a circa 1.2730 low, but remains capped well ahead of 1.2800 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty. The Franc veers from 0.9920-55 vs the Greenback and Kiwi hovers in a 0.6550-95 band, displaying more resilience than is antipodean peer on less exposure to Chine-US trade wars (and another rise in the PBoC’s Usd/Cny midpoint fix).

COMMODITIES

WTI (Unch) is flat on the day, while Brent (+0.3%) is modestly supported as US sanctions against Iran point towards tighter supply. WTI and Brent are in close proximity their 50 HMA to the downside at USD 67.14/bbl and USD 72.43/bbl respectively. Also of note: the OPEC Monthly Report is due to be released at 11:55BST. Elsewhere, spot gold fell to the lowest since March 15th 2017, weighed by the greenback as the yellow metal detaches itself from safe-haven properties. London copper is subdued on USD action and the risk-off sentiment.

India's Oil Corporation says Iran is giving insurance cover for oil shipments, having enough term oil shipments to cushion any Iranian shortfall. (Newswires)

Workers at three of Total’s North Sea oil platforms are to start a 12-hour strike at 12:00BST. (Newswires)

FX Morning Colour: scant respite despite widespread EM intervention
content:
TRY

The Lira remains front and centre of attention after more rousing attempts by Turkish President Erdogan to shore up the currency and coral support from the international investor community largely fell on deaf ears, with Usd/Try soaring through 7.0000 to a new record peak around 7.2150, and prompting the CBRT into action. However, still unable to intervene via conventional means (ie rate hikes) the Bank resorted to cutting Reserve Requirement Ratios for non-core FX liabilities by 400 bp alongside the Lira Required Reserve by 250 bp for all maturities, and the relief has been relatively limited as a result.

EM

Lira contagion has spread further across the region, with the Rand hit especially hard (Usd/Zar 15.4700+ at one stage , but the Idr, Twn and other Asian units also weakening to intervention tolerance levels, while the Mxn has unwound more NAFTA-related gains to trade back below 19.0000 vs the Usd.

DXY

Riding high amidst all the turmoil in high-beta/risk/yield currency counterparts, with the index just off fresh 2018 highs at 96.530, and now looking at chart targets ahead of 97.000 with fair resistance seen around 96.841.

JPY

Still bucking overall trends and outperforming due to its ultra safe-haven allure, with Usd/Jpy pulling back further from 111.00 and through 110.50 to test the water ahead of 110.00 where decent expiry option interest resides (1.3 bn up to 110.05 to be precise).

AUD/EUR   

The biggest G10 losers and most adversely impacted by broad risk aversion again, with Aud/Usd sitting mid-range between 0.7250-0.7300 and the single currency down through 1.1400 to test the 200 WMA at 1.1360 before regaining a degree of composure.

CAD/GBP/CHF/NZD

The Loonie is holding within a 1.3140-75 range vs its US rival and well off recent highs as Canada’s diplomatic row with Saudi Arabia rumbles on, while Cable has pared some losses from a circa 1.2730 low, but remains capped well ahead of 1.2800 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty. The Franc veers from 0.9920-55 vs the Greenback and Kiwi hovers in a 0.6550-95 band, displaying more resilience than is antipodean peer on less exposure to Chine-US trade wars (and another rise in the PBoC’s Usd/Cny midpoint fix).

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower across the board with sentiment in the region spooked on spill-over concerns as the Turkish lira extended on last week’s slump following a defiant tone from Turkish President Erdogan, which triggered capital control concerns and who labelled the weakness in TRY as a ‘currency plot’. This pressured the major indices from the get-go with ASX 200 (-0.6%) dragged by mining names, while Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) underperformed on safe-haven flows into JPY and with Mitsui Mining & Smelting down 15% post-earnings. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.7%) and Hang Seng (-1.9%) were also heavily weighed alongside the broad EM-triggered mayhem and continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices underpinned by safe-haven demand, although upside was also capped amid a lack of Rinban announcement with the BoJ only in the market for Treasury discount bills.

FTSE

British Business – Companies are struggling to fill vacancies as Brexit is affecting the supply of workers coming to the UK, forcing an increase in the starting wage offered. Alongside this Visa (V) found that spending was down 0.9% in July vs. prev. (Guardian)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Senior Tory MP Halfon has called for a fuel watchdog over concerns that the Asda merger will push up fuel prices and negatively affect motorists. (Times)

Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS LN) – Lawmakers have critiqued the FCA over not taking further action against the bank in regards to an investigation over the treatment of its customers. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Sports Direct International (SPD LN) – The takeover of House of Fraser is being scrutinised by regulators as thousands of workers have been left facing possible cuts to their pensions. (FT)

DAX

BMW (BMW GY) – The German carmaker is said to be facing China SUV import delays alongside Mercedes (DAI GY). (Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – An investor has said the co. needs a complete overhaul of the mid-term targets outlined last week, as these will not be enough to put the co. back on track, and has called for a new CEO to remedy this. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY)/Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Two automotive groups that represent the two co.’s have reportedly raised “significant concerns” over the US Governments request for confidential business information in a probe over the threat to US national security. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Monsanto has been ordered to pay USD 289mln as a penalty since the co. has been proven to have caused a farmers terminal cancer. (Guardian)

Commerzbank (CBK GY) – A board member told a German newspaper that they plan to step up their expansion plans by having a stronger push on private and business customers. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Fraport (FRA GY) – Report 6.9mln passengers welcomed, +7.5%, passenger growth of 8.8%, hit a new daily record of 238k passengers achieved at FRA. (Newswires)

1&1 Dillisch (DRI GY) – Revenue +15% to EUR 1.819bln, EBITDA +61.9% to EUR 340.1mln, FY forecast confirmed. (Newswires)

Scout24 (G24 GY) – H1 profit after tax EUR 66.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 54.9mln, revenue EUR 251.2mln, on track to achieve guidance for FY. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

COMMERZBANK (CBK GY) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

BAYER (BAYN GY) DOWNGRADED TO MARKETPERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT MAINFIRST

CAC

Air France (AF FP) – The Dutch pilot union has threatened to strike, while setting a deadline for the Co. (Newswires)

Total (FP FP) – According to Iran state news, China’s CNPC is to take over Co. share of the Iranian gas project. (Newswires)

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – FDA grants breakthrough therapy designation for Xolair (Omalizumab) for food allergies. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

AMADEUS (AMS SM) – To acquire Travelclick from Thoma Bravo for USD 1.52bln in Q4 2018, over 1000 Travelclick employees to join Amadeus. They expect proforma combined revenue of EUR 5.06bln, combined EBITDA of EUR 2.02bln and combined EBITDA margin of 40%; all post transaction. (Newswires)

US

* SPX -0.71% at 2833, NDX -0.79% at 7408, DJI -0.77% at 25313. SECTORS: Energy +0.26%, Materials -1.43%, Industrials -0.81% Cons Discretionary -0.82%, Cons Staples 0.32%, Healthcare -0.39%, Financials -1.16%, Tech -0.81%, Telecoms -0.75%, Utilities -0.41%.

* FUTURES: US futures followed on from the selloff in European equities amid the ongoing concerns in Turkey, which saw the Nasdaq snap its 8th daily consecutive gain. However the morning sell off in the US futures complex  calmed down but stocks were further pressured as Turkey announced they will retaliate as necessary to the ‘doubling’ tariffs,  extending losses to just shy of 1% before the near agreement on Pastor Brunson was announced which saw a small reversal.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week lower across the board with sentiment in the region spooked on spill-over concerns as the Turkish lira extended on last week’s slump
  • Sell-off in TRY sparks EM currency sell-off although TRY later found support on announcement of measures
  • Looking ahead, today’s calendar lacks tier 1 data

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower across the board with sentiment in the region spooked on spill-over concerns as the Turkish lira extended on last week’s slump following a defiant tone from Turkish President Erdogan, which triggered capital control concerns and who labelled the weakness in TRY as a ‘currency plot’. This pressured the major indices from the get-go with ASX 200 (-0.6%) dragged by mining names, while Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) underperformed on safe-haven flows into JPY and with Mitsui Mining & Smelting down 15% post-earnings. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.7%) and Hang Seng (-1.9%) were also heavily weighed alongside the broad EM-triggered mayhem and continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices underpinned by safe-haven demand, although upside was also capped amid a lack of Rinban announcement with the BoJ only in the market for Treasury discount bills.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8629 (Prev. 6.8395)


UK/EU

UK Visa Consumer Spending fell 0.9% Y/Y in July vs. Prev. increase of 0.7% in June. (Newswires)

UK employers expect to offer median pay increases of 2.0% over next 12 months which was inline Q/Q. (Newswires)

Trade experts warn UK PM May the Brexit tariff plan is “fanciful”, while also questioning the reliability to track goods. (Times)

Senior Brussel figure stated the immediate consequence of a no-deal Brexit could be worse for the EU than the UK. This comes ahead of the next round of Brexit talks scheduled for Thursday. (Times)

The UK is working on options to avoid a hard border with Ireland; according to people familiar with the matter. One option would effectively prolong large parts of the transition phase; according to one official. (Newswires)

According to a major new poll, more than 100 parliamentary seats that backed Brexit in 2016 have flipped to support staying in the EU. (Sky News)

Fitch upgraded Greece by 2 notches to BB- from B; Outlook Stable and reaffirmed Lithuania at A-; Outlook revised to positive. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, USD/TRY initially surged over 10% against the greenback to above the 7.0000 handle in continuation of the TRY sell-off and after a defiant tone from President Erdogan. This was then brought back down after measures from Turkey in which the banking regulator placed a limit on FX swaps, although the support was brief and USD/TRY resumed its surge and homed in on the earlier record highs. This triggered EM currency contagion fears in which ZAR slumped as much as 10% to its lowest in over 2 years, while TWD fell to its weakest since March 2017 and IDR declined to a near 3-year low which prompted Bank Indonesia intervention. The turmoil underpinned safe-haven currencies across the board with JPY the notable benefactor, while USD also strengthened against most its major counterparts which saw EUR/USD slip below 1.1400 and AUD/USD relinquish the 0.7300 handle.

Turkish President Erdogan stated the economy is not in a crisis and that weakness in TRY is a currency plot, while he added that Turkey will win this economic war and are undergoing preparations to use national currencies for trade with nations such as China and Russia. There were also comments from Turkish Finance Minister Albayrak that the government has an action plan regarding the currency and will take necessary measures on Monday to ease market concerns, while he stated they will not convert nor seize FX deposits and that the currency is being directly targeted by the US President. In related news, Turkish Presidency Communication Chief Altun stated Erdogan’s comments were a warning against FX flight, while the banking regulator also announced to limit swap transactions in which banks’ total swap transactions has been capped at 50% of banks’ equity. (Newswires)

Turkish Central Bank has reduced the Reserve Requirement Ratios for non-core FX liabilities by 400BPS alongside the Lira Required Reserved reduced by 250BPS for all maturities. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre overnight with demand sapped by a broad risk-averse tone and as focus centred on the sell-off across EM currencies. As such, WTI crude futures were relatively flat as the rebound from Friday stalled ahead of the USD 68.00/bbl level, while metals were also uneventful in which gold was subdued by a firmer green back and copper languished amid the risk averse tone.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (10 Aug) 1057 (Prev. 1044). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Turkish Foreign Ministry stated that Turkey will retaliate as necessary to the latest US tariffs after President Trump tweeted that he authorised a double up on tariffs on steel and aluminium with respect to Turkey. However, there were also comments late on Friday from Trump Lawyer Sekulow that they are close to reaching an agreement on Pastor Brunson. (Newswires)

North Korea reportedly rejected several denuclearization proposals made by the US. (CNN)

Officials on Friday stated that Iran conducted a test launch of a ballistic missile which was its first for the year. (Fox)
 

US

Treasuries rallied throughout the day, with yields falling to a 3week low at one point, as risk-aversion spurred by the currency crisis in Turkey shifted investors’ position away from risky assets into a bid for safe-havens. Amid decent volume, the short end of the curve was hit more than the long end; 5yr yields were lower by c.7bps and 30yr yields were lower by c.6bps.The 10yr yield posted the biggest one-day fall since late May, hitting a low of 2.85%. 2s5s narrowed by c2.5bps, 2s10 by c.2bps, whilst 5s30 widened by c.1.5bps. US 10YR T-notes settled 21 ticks higher at 120-12.

US President Trump stated that a deal with Mexico is coming along nicely and that Canada must wait. In related news, there were comments on Friday from Mexico’s Economy Minister that NAFTA talks have progressed well that week and will do the upcoming week also. (Twitter/Newswires)

Russian Finance Minister Siluanov stated that Russia will further reduce holdings of US securities in response to sanctions, but is not planning to shut down US firms. (FT)

subject: Bunds: slow drift from early Eurex highs
content: It’s been a gradual retracement from an initial mark-up for the 10 year German debt future, eyeing latest Lira moves in the FX markets, and also keeping tabs on BTPs, but the former and related knock-on impact to broad risk sentiment appears more prescient at present. Indeed, Bunds have only traded lower off the 163.46 open vs last Friday’s 163.34 close to a 163.22 low before finding some underlying bids/support as the 10 year Italian benchmark lost grip of the 124.00 handle. Back to Usd/Try, price action remains very volatile (understandably), but 7.0000 seems to be a line in the sand. Ahead, Italian CPI data due, but unlikely to impact too much.
